bug.description:
<denchmark-h:h5>System information (version)</denchmark-h>


OpenCV => 3.3
Operating System / Platform => Ubuntu 16.04
Compiler => g++

<denchmark-h:h5>Detailed description</denchmark-h>

integer overflow in ReadNumber
/home/scdeny/github/opencv/modules/imgcodecs/src/grfmt_pxm.cpp:83:18: runtime error: signed integer overflow: 555555555 * 10 cannot be represented in type 'int'
static int ReadNumber( RLByteStream& strm, int maxdigits  )
81:
do
{
val = val*10 + code - '0';
if( ++digits >= maxdigits ) break;
code = strm.getByte();
}
while( isdigit(code));
<denchmark-h:h5>Steps to reproduce</denchmark-h>

cv::imread("2.ReadNumber_int_overflow_poc")
poc is here:
<denchmark-link:https://github.com/scdeny/opencv_pocs/blob/master/2.ReadNumber_int_overflow_poc>https://github.com/scdeny/opencv_pocs/blob/master/2.ReadNumber_int_overflow_poc</denchmark-link>

comments.comment:
I suggest you to use github feature to
Link to the source code , not just writing it down Highlight the source code
cv::imread("2.ReadNumber_int_overflow_poc"); and also
Provide more specific compiler version
probably the cmake version and also the cmake options you used. It'll help a LOT for the others much much more than you imagine.
BTW, the number written in the file is large, so raising a run time error looks valid behavior to me. What did you expect to see ?

Thanks for your suggestion! I will do that next time. I compile opencv this (GCC Undefined Behavior Sanitizer â€“ <denchmark-link:https://developers.redhat.com/blog/2014/10/16/gcc-undefined-behavior-sanitizer-ubsan/>ubsan)</denchmark-link>
cmake -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug -DCMAKE_CXX_FLAGS="-fsanitize=address,undefined" cmake version 3.8.2 so the integer overflow warning is printed, or else will cause unpredictable errors
probably it's better to <denchmark-link:http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2017-12864>link</denchmark-link> , not just writing down. nice work !
